awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Advancing the science and education of land surface-atmosphere interactions: Interweaving multiscale experimental and modeling approaches for  Land Surface Models
awd_abstract_narration:
CAREER: Advancing the science and education of land surface-atmosphere interactions: Interweaving multiscale experimental and modeling approaches for 
Land Surface Models and experiential learning

	A critical challenge for Land Surface Models (LSMs) is to simulate processes at the surface and the subsurface and their feedbacks to the atmosphere. Even given the same climate forcings, LSMs predict different surface fluxes and soil moisture conditions. This is due to differences in the formulations of individual processes, parameterizations of those formulations, numerical solution methods and representation of spatial heterogeneity. All of these differences contribute to LSM prediction errors and uncertainty.  Increasing confidence in climate predictions requires revisiting fundamental process understanding and using that understanding to improve representations of land-atmosphere feedbacks. This research seeks to address this challenge by answering questions on multiphase fluid transport mechanisms in surface soils and mass/energy exchange at the soil-atmosphere interface. New knowledge and modeling approaches will result in improved predictions for water supply and food security as well as environmental issues across the nation. Linked to the research plan is an educational framework for engaging minority middle school students in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM).  Focusing on the integrating theme of water and climate, the investigator will help students make the link between STEM they learn in the classroom and environmental water resource problems in their own backyards, motivating and preparing students to pursue college studies and ultimately careers in STEM fields. The integrated activities will help to build a scientifically literate and informed citizenry, while also answering critical water and climate questions. This project will contribute substantially to the goals of the NSF in the production of interdisciplinary knowledge and the education of middle-school students, young scientists and engineers. 

	The overarching goal of this research is to advance our understanding and modeling of mass and energy exchange at the land-atmosphere interface over a wide range of scales, and ultimately improve LSMs that are utilized in global climate prediction. The proposed research will systematically explore how the shallow subsurface and the atmosphere, specifically the layer very close to the soil surface, interact, providing new insights into mass and thermal flux process interactions that will be integrated into LSMs. A focus on scaling based on process understanding at multiple scales will allow for process-rich parameterizations for multiple land-atmosphere interaction and subsurface processes that contribute to LSMs. This vision includes unique highly controlled mechanistic studies in the laboratory, leveraging of existing laboratory and field data, modeling of critical mass and energy dynamics, and the characterization of important interactions from the laboratory to the watershed scales that drive feedbacks to climate systems. Project results will yield unique, high-fidelity data that will greatly aid in improving our understanding and modeling of the processes affected by heterogeneity at various scales and the development of methods to mechanistically represent the proposed processes at the watershed scale. A suite of climate intermediate, and fine scale computational models will be used to guide observations and interpret data; process studies will provide new algorithms and process parameterizations and evaluate model performance. Computational models in conjunction with experimental data will enable the investigator to understand governing flow and transport mechanisms under different atmospheric forcing at different scales.  This research is expected to improve the representation of mass and energy exchange processes across multiple scales at the soil-land-atmosphere interface.

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT:  This research answered fundamental questions on multiphase fluid transport mechanisms in surface soils and mass, and energy exchange at the soil-atmosphere interface. Project results improve our understanding and modeling of evaporation at various scales. We used particle imaging velocimetry (PIV) linked with measurement of soil, surface and atmospheric conditions to obtain high resolution data on flux exchange processes.  Data was used to evaluate physical behavior and make improvements to the prediction of evaporation through the development of new parameters and models.  Specifically, we developed new atmospheric and soil surface resistance parameters to improve the predictions of the evaporation rate and soil evaporation efficiency in modeling hydrological and energy cycles through proper characterization of the near surface atmospheric conditions which are depend on the microtopography and the wind velocity. Methods were further tested at the field scale using lysimeter experiments. The extensions to the field allowed for improvements to the prediction of evaporation through the development and testing of a physically-based dry surface layer model.  New physical understanding of soil layering showed how the soil layering configuration has significant impact on the evolution of soil moisture profiles and evaporation dynamics, the extent of which depends on the layering sequence, thickness, and properties of each layer.  Findings also showed how the near-surface wind impacts gases differently due to gas density ,demonstrating how dense and light gases cannot be treated as inert tracers, but rather the importance of taking the gas density into account. 

Educational findings show the importance of role models in influencing the involvement and attitudes of middle school students towards STEM. Educational assessment results are relevant to the future of STEM educational outreach, specifically the impact of mentors on future workforce development. The on-going STEM mentoring and tutoring program at a public middle school can be used as a framework for STEM programs.  The bilingual STEM education website increases access to  education resources in English and Spanish speaking classrooms. The site includes education modules for teachers and middle school students on climate, watersheds, contamination, and water and waste management.

BROADER IMPACTS:  This research has broader societal impacts in two ways.  First, findings improve the representation of mass and energy exchange processes at the soil-land-atmosphere interface which contributes towards addressing critical problems of water supply, climate change and food security.This work applies to studies that include natural or engineered topographical structures such as erosion patterns,  bogs in boreal forests and plowed agricultural fields. Modeling concepts for evaporation are relevant to other disciplines and research areas to include improving processes in the food production chain, the drying of fruits and vegetables, drying of porous material (e.g. concrete), cooling strategies for rocket engines, salinization of agricultural used soil, and the leakage of hazardous gaseous compounds from soil.

Secondly, this research contributed to human capacity building through experiential education focusing on female minority students.  This project contributed substantially to the goals of the NSF in the production of interdisciplinary knowledge and the education of middle-school students, young scientists and engineers. Focusing on the integrating theme of water and climate, this research helped students make the link between Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) they learn in the classroom and environmental water resource problems in their own backyards, motivating and preparing students to pursue college studies and ultimately careers in STEM fields.

The project has resulted in the education of future generations from middle school through graduate school as well as contributed to community outreach and education.  Six graduate students were funded as part of this award while and additional four graduate students were involved in this award but funded by external scholarships and fellowships.  Eight undergraduate engineering students at the University of Texas at Arlington and Colorado School of Mines participated in this research as undergraduate research interns.  41 undergraduate students served as mentors and tutors to middle school students throughout this work resulting in over 1800 hours of tutoring and mentoring.  Three of the undergraduate students went on to careers in K-12 STEM education. Research and education results have been disseminated through 22 peer reviewed journal publications, 50  presentations, 10 public interest science and news articles, and the PIs website.  A new bilingual educational outreach website provides educational modules on environmental issues.  All data is publicly available and published in online data repositories.
